questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after he lost consciousness. He was playing with his 3-year-old granddaughter when he suddenly collapsed and was unresponsive for 1 minute. He responded normally after regaining consciousness. He has had episodes of mild chest pain and abdominal discomfort for the past 2 months, especially while working on his car. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. He appears alert. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 89/min and regular, and blood pressure is 110/88 mm Hg. Examination shows a grade 3/6 late systolic murmur at the right sternal border that radiates to the carotids. There is no swelling or erythema of the lower extremities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the chordae tendineae can lead to mitral regurgitation (MR), which also manifests with a systolic murmur. However, the murmur in MR is typically heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla and not the carotids. Also, rupture of the chordae tendineae results in acute MR, most likely leading to severe symptoms such as pulmonary edema or even cardiogenic shock.

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis of the sinus node is a cause of sick sinus syndrome (SSS), which may manifest with syncope and angina. However, SSS cannot account for this patient's heart murmur.

C) INCORRECT:

Asymmetric hypertrophy of the septal myocardium is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which can also cause a systolic murmur and manifest with angina or syncope on exertion. However, HCM is a congenital disease that typically develops in younger patients; it would be unusual for the disease to manifest for the first time in an older patient.
Image Description:

Transthoracic echocardiogram (apical three-chamber view)

The walls of the left ventricle are asymmetrically hypertrophied. Compared to normal findings (green dashed outline), the interventricular septum (red overlay) is markedly thickened (green arrows). The lateral wall is also thickened, but not to the same extent as the interventricular septum.

These findings are suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. To assess for left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction, the LVOT pressure gradient during systole should be measured.

LW: lateral wall; LV: left ventricle; IVS: interventricular septum; MV: mitral valve; AV: aortic valve; LA: left atrium

D) CORRECT:

This patient has aortic stenosis (AS), most likely secondary to calcification and fibrosis of the aortic valve, which becomes more prevalent with older age. The increased afterload created by the stenotic aortic valve reduces cardiac output, which results in angina, syncope, and ultimately, heart failure. Other common underlying risk factors for AS, especially in younger patients, include bicuspid aortic valves and a history of rheumatic fever.

To confirm this patient's diagnosis and evaluate the extent of AS, the next best diagnostic step would be to perform transthoracic echocardiography.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's syncope may be due to pulmonary embolism (PE), PE severe enough to cause syncope would not resolve on its own nor be asymptomatic after the event. Instead, dyspnea, chest pain, hypotension, and/or tachycardia would have been present, making PE very unlikely.
questions.hint: A decreased pulse pressure (difference between the systolic and diastolic pressures) is a common feature of this condition.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by his wife. Thirty minutes ago, he was carrying boxes from his house to a truck when he felt short of breath and suddenly lost consciousness. His wife states that he fell to the ground and was unresponsive for 15 seconds before he regained consciousness. He was not confused after this episode. He does not have chest pain. On questioning, he recalls experiencing episodic shortness of breath and chest tightness while playing tennis over the past year. These symptoms resolved with rest. He has no personal history of serious illness and takes no medication. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 95/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 102/81 mm Hg. Physical examination shows delayed peripheral pulses. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coronary angiography is a diagnostic test for patients with anginal symptoms due to coronary artery disease (CAD). This patient has a history of chest tightness on exertion, which is likely ischemic in nature. However, CAD rarely manifests with syncope. In addition, most patients with CAD have several risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and a family history of cardiac disease, none of which are seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is a diagnostic test for pulmonary embolism (PE) and aortic dissection. This patient lacks a history of pleuritic chest pain, acute worsening dyspnea, immobility, deep vein thrombosis, or a hypercoagulable state that would raise suspicion of PE. Aortic dissection manifests as the sudden onset of acute, sharp/tearing chest pain radiating to the back, which is not present here.

C) CORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is the best confirmatory test in patients with suspected aortic stenosis (AS), the most likely cause of this patient's syncope. In early stages of AS, patients are typically asymptomatic at rest. However, during exertion, peripheral vasodilation occurs to increase blood flow to muscles. If stenosis at the aortic valve is severe enough, it obstructs blood flow, thereby preventing an increase in cardiac output to maintain blood pressure during exertion, which leads to hypotension, decreased cerebral blood flow, syncope, dizziness, dyspnea, and angina pectoris. A delayed pulse supports this diagnosis. Cardiac auscultation typically shows a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur.
Image Description:

Echocardiography (transthoracic; apical five-chamber view; with CW Doppler)

The aortic valve is hyperechoic due to calcification and fibrosis of the valve leaflets.Transaortic velocity measures 4.01 m/s and the mean aortic pressure gradient measures 42.2 mmHg. From these measurements, the aortic valve stenosis would be classified as stage C2.

D) INCORRECT:

The tilt table test is used to diagnose orthostatic hypotension (postural hypotension). Orthostatic syncope may occur when suddenly standing up after prolonged sitting or lying down, which is not what precipitated this patient's syncope. Although this patient's blood pressure is on the low side, his clinical presentation and history of chest pain on exertion are less suggestive of orthostasis as the cause of syncope.

E) INCORRECT:

Continuous ambulatory ECG monitoring (Holter monitoring) is used for 24–48 hours to monitor for possible arrhythmias that are not as easily detected on routine ECG. However, episodes of syncope are usually not frequent enough to be detectable in such a short period of time. Moreover, this patient has a regular pulse on physical examination, which makes an arrhythmia less likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Analysis of cardiac enzymes such as troponins and CK-MB should always be ordered in patients with retrosternal chest pain on exertion and/or worsening chest pain at rest. However, this patient presents with syncope, not chest pain: his presentation is not consistent with acute coronary syndrome.

G) INCORRECT:

Carotid duplex ultrasonography is the first-line diagnostic test in patients with symptomatic carotid artery stenosis, which may manifest with syncope. However, isolated syncope is rare and is typically accompanied by focal neurological symptoms (e.g., due to transient ischemic attack or stroke), which are not seen in this patient. In addition, delayed pulses and low pulse pressure are not characteristic of carotid stenosis.

H) INCORRECT:

EEG is the diagnostic test of choice in patients whose syncope is believed to result from seizure. This patient does not have a history of previous convulsions, electrolyte abnormalities, or other possible causes of seizures. Furthermore, physical examination that shows delayed pulse, low blood pressure, and the lack of confusion on regaining consciousness (postictal state) make seizure an unlikely diagnosis.
questions.hint: Cardiac auscultation would likely provide another diagnostic clue.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of episodic retrosternal pain and shortness of breath. The episodes occur when he climbs stairs or tries to walk briskly on his treadmill. The symptoms resolve with rest. The previous evening he felt dizzy and weak during such an episode. He also reports that he had a cold 2 weeks ago. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 4 years ago but is otherwise healthy. His only medication is glyburide. He appears well. His pulse is 62/min and weak, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 134/90 mm Hg. Cardiovascular examination shows a late systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the second right intercostal space. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following mechanisms is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Narrowing of the coronary arterial lumen
Critical transmural hypoperfusion of the myocardium
Cellular injury of the esophageal epithelium

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In AS, blood flow from the left ventricle to the aorta is obstructed by the narrowed aortic valve opening (increased afterload), which, over time, results in left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). LVH leads to increased left ventricular oxygen demand, resulting in myocardial ischemia (angina) during periods of strenuous exercise or stress. The inability to maintain cardiac output during exertion causes transient cerebral hypoperfusion and, therefore, presyncope or syncope.

The presence of symptoms in patients with AS is an indication for surgical repair, as symptomatic AS carries a poor prognosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Lymphocytic infiltration of the myocardium is the underlying mechanism of viral myocarditis, which classically manifests with symptoms of heart failure after a recent viral illness. Although this patient recently had a cold, he does not have any other symptoms of viral myocarditis (e.g., fatigue, low-grade fever, orthopnea). Furthermore, this patient's presentation is consistent with AS, which suggests that a different mechanism is responsible for his symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Narrowing of the coronary arteries is the underlying mechanism of coronary artery disease (CAD), which can result in myocardial ischemia due to inadequate oxygen supply to the myocardium during exertion. While this patient has angina and strong risk factors for CAD (e.g., older age, diabetes), his presyncopal symptoms and heart murmur are consistent with AS, which suggests that a different mechanism is responsible for his symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammation and constriction of the bronchioles is the underlying mechanism of virus-induced bronchospasm. Common respiratory viruses (as this patient likely had) can cause epithelial damage to the airways, induce inflammation and bronchospasm, and subsequently trigger wheezing in both patients with and without underlying asthma. While his recent cold and exertional dyspnea could be consistent with bronchospasm, his presyncopal symptoms and heart murmur suggest that a different mechanism may be responsible for this patient's symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Critical transmural hypoperfusion of the myocardium is the underlying mechanism of myocardial infarction (MI), a form of acute coronary syndrome. This patient's symptoms are transient and resolve with rest, which, alongside the presence of weak peripheral pulses and a heart murmur, is consistent with AS; a different mechanism is responsible for his symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Injury to the esophageal epithelium is the underlying mechanism of GERD, and is secondary to acid exposure from reflux of gastric contents. GERD should always be considered in the differential for chest pain, as it may commonly present with atypical chest pain. However, this patient presents with typical chest pain (e.g., retrosternal, exertional, resolves with rest) consistent with angina, and his presyncopal symptoms and heart murmur suggest a different mechanism.

G) INCORRECT:

Catecholamine-induced transient regional systolic dysfunction is the underlying mechanism of stress cardiomyopathy, a reversible form of myocardial dysfunction that is often induced by stress or trauma. The clinical presentation typically resembles that of acute coronary syndrome or acute decompensated heart failure. However, this patient's symptoms and heart murmur are consistent with AS, which suggests that a different mechanism is responsible for his symptoms.

H) INCORRECT:

Glyburide, a sulfonylurea used for the treatment of diabetes, increases endogenous insulin secretion by inhibiting ATP-sensitive potassium channels in pancreatic beta cells. Sulfonylureas should be used cautiously in elderly patients given the risk of inducing hypoglycemia. While hypoglycemia could certainly cause presyncopal symptoms, it would not explain his exertional chest pain or heart murmur.
questions.hint: The three major symptoms associated with aortic stenosis (AS) can be remembered using the SAD mnemonic: Syncope, Angina, and Dyspnea.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month. He reports that he cannot climb more than one flight of stairs without experiencing shortness of breath and dizziness. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and low-dose aspirin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He does not drink alcohol. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Severe aortic regurgitation (AR) can manifest with dizziness and exertional dyspnea, as seen here. However, patients with AR typically present with high pulse pressure, a water hammer pulse, and a high-pitched early diastolic murmur heard best at the left 3rd ICS that does not radiate to the carotid arteries.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid stenosis (TS) is extremely rare and typically manifests with abdominal discomfort (due to hepatomegaly) and other features of right-sided heart failure, which are not present here. In addition, the typical murmur of TS is a soft middiastolic murmur heard best in the parasternal region of the left 4th ICS.
Image Description:

Delayed diastolic murmur with a decrescendo, possible presystolic crescendo

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary regurgitation (PR) is usually asymptomatic but can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. However, features of right-sided heart failure would be present, and auscultation in PR would show an early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard parasternally at the left 2nd ICS.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is typically asymptomatic but can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. However, auscultation of an MVP shows a high-frequency, midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur that is heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is extremely rare and in severe cases manifests with abdominal discomfort (due to hepatomegaly) and other features of right-sided heart failure, which are not present here. In addition, the murmur of TR is holosystolic and heard best in the parasternal region of the left 4th ICS.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

F) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen here. However, auscultation in MS shows a middiastolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular left 5th ICS (the apex) and is often preceded by an opening snap.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

G) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultation findings are consistent with aortic stenosis, which causes left ventricular outflow obstruction. The result is dizziness and exacerbation of dyspnea upon exertion, and weak peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus). Incomplete left ventricular emptying may also cause pulmonary venous congestion, which further exacerbates dyspnea.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

H) INCORRECT:

Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, patients with MR typically present with normal peripheral pulses and a holosystolic high-pitched murmur heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS that radiates to the left axilla.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

I) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is mostly a congenital valve defect that can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. However, cardiac auscultation typically shows an ejection systolic murmur best heard at the left 2nd ICS.
Image Description:

Crescendo-decrescendo murmur with ejection click and widely split second heart sound
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space (ICS) that radiates to the carotids. These features are suggestive of the most common valvular heart disease in industrialized countries.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man comes to the physician because of increased exertional dyspnea and dizziness over the past 8 weeks. He has hypertension for which he takes lisinopril. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is mostly a congenital valve defect that can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. In adults, common causes include carcinoid syndrome and chronic rheumatic fever. But auscultation yields an ejection systolic murmur best heard in the left 2nd ICS.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, patients with MR would have normal peripheral pulses and a holosystolic high-pitched murmur heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS that radiates to the left axilla.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultation findings are consistent with aortic stenosis (AS), which causes left ventricular outflow obstruction. The result is dizziness and exacerbation of dyspnea upon exertion, and weak, delayed peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus). Incomplete left ventricular emptying may also cause pulmonary venous congestion, which further exacerbates dyspnea.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is typically asymptomatic but can also present with exertional dyspnea. However, auscultation of an MVP shows a high-frequency, midsystolic click with a late systolic murmur that is heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS.
Image Description:

High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, auscultation in MS yields a mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular 5th left ICS (the apex), and is often preceded by an opening snap.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

F) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary regurgitation (PR) is usually asymptomatic but can also manifest as exertional dyspnea. However, features of right-sided heart failure would be present, and auscultation in PR would show an early diastolic decrescendo murmur that is best heard parasternally in the left 2nd ICS.

G) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid stenosis (TS) is extremely rare and typically presents with abdominal discomfort (due to hepatomegaly) and other features of right-sided heart failure, which are not present here. In addition, the typical murmur of TS is a soft mid-diastolic murmur heard best in the parasternal region of the left 4th ICS.

H) INCORRECT:

Patients with severe aortic regurgitation can present with dizziness and exertional dyspnea, like this patient. However, examination in AR would show a high pulse pressure, a water hammer pulse, and a high-pitched early diastolic murmur heard best at the 2nd right ICS that does not radiate to the carotid arteries.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.

I) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is extremely rare and in severe cases presents with abdominal discomfort (due to hepatomegaly) and other features of right-sided heart failure, which are not present here. In addition, the murmur of TR is holosystolic and heard best in the parasternal region of the left 4th ICS.
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space (ICS) that radiates to the carotids. These features are suggestive of the most common valvular heart disease in industrialized countries.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after an episode of dizziness and loss of consciousness that lasted 10 seconds. The symptoms occurred while the patient was exercising in an aerobics class. She has a 3-year history of progressive shortness of breath and chest discomfort on exertion. Radial pulses are decreased and delayed bilaterally. The patient most likely has a murmur starting at which of the following labeled points in the curve shown?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This point on the volume/pressure curve corresponds to the beginning of the left ventricular contraction and the closure of the mitral valve. During this period, the ventricular pressure rises without changes in volume (isovolumetric contraction). Hence the aortic valve remains closed until the pressure between aorta and ventricle is equalized. Since there is no blood flowing through the valve, aortic stenosis murmur would not be heard at this point.

B) CORRECT:

This point on the left ventricular volume/pressure curve corresponds to the opening of the aortic valve. Patients with aortic valve stenosis (AS) typically present with a crescendo-decrescendo, systolic, ejection murmur that begins at this point (shortly after the S1) and finishes before the S2.

C) INCORRECT:

This point indicates the beginning of diastole and corresponds to the closure of the aortic valve. When the pressure inside the ventricle falls below the aortic pressure, the aortic valve closes and a period of isovolumetric relaxation occurs. The murmur associated with aortic stenosis is produced during systole, and would therefore not be found at this point.

D) INCORRECT:

This point corresponds to the opening of the mitral valve and indicates the beginning of the passive filling phase of the ventricle. The murmur encountered in this patient would occur during systole, as the blood flows from the left ventricle to the aorta, but not during diastole while the ventricle is being passively filled.

E) INCORRECT:

This point represents the left atrial contraction and the left ventricular rapid filling phase. While the left ventricle continues to relax during diastole, the left atria forces more blood flow across the mitral valve. Mitral valve stenosis murmurs rather than aortic stenosis murmurs would be heard at this point. Mitral valve stenosis is associated with dyspnea on exertion but less commonly with angina pectoris. It is not associated with exertional dizziness, syncope, or pulsus parvus et tardus.
questions.hint: The patient has a history of exertional dyspnea and angina pectoris and presents with exertional syncope. Examination shows pulsus parvus et tardus. These signs and symptoms are most consistent with aortic valve stenosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician for chest tightness, shortness of breath, and lightheadedness. She has experienced these symptoms during the past 2 weeks while climbing stairs but feels better when she sits down. She had a cold 2 weeks ago but has otherwise been well. She appears short of breath. Her respirations are 21/min and blood pressure is 131/85 mm Hg. On cardiovascular examination, a late systolic ejection murmur is heard best in the second right intercostal space. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following mechanisms is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Narrowing of the coronary arterial lumen
Cellular injury of the esophageal epithelium
Critical transmural hypoperfusion of the myocardium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A combination of inflammation and constriction of the bronchioles describes the mechanism behind virus-induced bronchospasm. Common respiratory viruses (as this patient likely had) can cause epithelial damage to the airways, induce inflammation and bronchospasm, and subsequently trigger wheezing in both patients with and without underlying asthma. While her recent cold and exertional dyspnea could be consistent with bronchospasm, her presyncopal symptoms and heart murmur suggest a different mechanism.

B) INCORRECT:

Narrowing of the coronary arteries describes the mechanism of coronary artery disease (CAD), which can result in myocardial ischemia due to inadequate oxygen supply to the myocardium during exertion. While this patient clearly has angina, as well as strong risk factors for CAD (age), her presyncopal symptoms and heart murmur are not explained by CAD alone and a different mechanism is more likely to be the cause of her symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Injury to the esophageal epithelium is the mechanism behind GERD and is secondary to acid exposure from reflux of gastric contents. GERD should always be considered in the differential for chest pain, as it may commonly present with atypical chest pain. However, this patient presents with typical chest pain (e.g., exertional chest tightness that resolves with rest) consistent with angina, and her presyncopal symptoms and heart murmur suggest a different mechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

Critical transmural hypoperfusion of the myocardium describes the mechanism behind myocardial infarction (MI), a form of acute coronary syndrome. This patient's symptoms, while concerning, are transient and resolve with rest, making acute MI very unlikely. Her heart murmur make a different mechanism more likely.

E) CORRECT:

The narrowed opening of a stenotic aortic valve during systole obstructs blood flow from the left ventricle (LV), which over time results in left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH). LVH subsequently results in increased LV oxygen demand, leading to myocardial ischemia, which manifests as angina, especially during periods of strenuous exercise or stress. The reduction in cardiac output during exertion also causes transient cerebral hypoperfusion, which explains her presyncopal symptoms.

The presence of symptoms with aortic stenosis (AS) is an indication for surgical repair, as symptomatic AS carries a poor prognosis.
questions.hint: This patient is presenting with chest tightness consistent with angina. She also has a late ejection systolic murmur on examination, which should raise suspicion of aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband 20 minutes after losing consciousness. She was walking briskly with her husband when she collapsed suddenly. Her husband says that she regained consciousness after 1 minute. She has had episodes of mild chest pain for the past 2 months, especially when working in the garden. Physical examination shows a grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur. The intensity of the murmur decreases with the handgrip maneuver and does not change with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Cystic medial degeneration of the aortic root
Sterile platelet thrombi on the mitral valve
Infected fibrin aggregates on the tricuspid valve
Dystrophic calcification on the aortic valve
Granulomatous nodules on the mitral valve
Congenital leaflet fusion of the aortic valve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystic medial degeneration of the aortic root, which occurs in Marfan syndrome, can lead to aortic regurgitation. Unlike this patient's murmur, the murmur of aortic regurgitation is holodiastolic and accentuated by maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip). Moreover, this patient does not have any features that suggest a diagnosis of Marfan syndrome (e.g., long extremities, hypermobile joints, arachnodactyly, blurred vision due to lens dislocation).

B) INCORRECT:

Sterile platelet thrombi on the mitral valve are characteristic of nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE), which can occur in individuals with rheumatologic disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus) or malignancies. NBTE can result in mitral regurgitation. Unlike this patient's murmur, the murmur of mitral regurgitation is holosystolic. Moreover, this patient lacks manifestations that suggest an underlying rheumatologic disorder (e.g., fever, joint pain, malaise) and does not have a known malignancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Infected fibrin aggregates on heart valves are seen in individuals with infective endocarditis (IE). Tricuspid valve involvement (e.g., from intravenous drug use) results in tricuspid regurgitation. Unlike this patient's murmur, the murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is holosystolic. Moreover, this patient does not have typical manifestations of IE (e.g., fever, malaise).

D) CORRECT:

The most common cause of aortic valve stenosis (AS) is dystrophic calcification of the aortic valve. AS is the most common valvular abnormality in adults > 65 years of age. Typical symptoms include syncope (especially during physical exercise), angina pectoris, and dyspnea (typically exertional). Cardiac auscultation in a patient with AS typically reveals a mid-to-late-peaking systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is heard best at the aortic area (right upper sternal border). Maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., sustained handgrip) decrease the intensity of the murmur.

E) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous nodules on the mitral valve are associated with rheumatic heart disease (RHD) and can result in mitral regurgitation. RHD typically manifests during adolescence or early adulthood and is an unlikely underlying cause of a murmur in this 79-year-old patient. Moreover, the handgrip maneuver increases the intensity of the murmur of mitral regurgitation.

F) INCORRECT:

A bicuspid aortic valve due to congenital fusion of the aortic valve leaflets can lead to aortic stenosis and manifest with syncope, chest pain, and a late-peaking systolic murmur that decreases in intensity with the handgrip maneuver. However, aortic stenosis due to a bicuspid valve typically becomes symptomatic in the fourth or fifth decade of life. This 79-year-old patient is more likely to have aortic stenosis of a different etiology.
questions.hint: Physical examination of this patient is likely to show pulsus parvus et tardus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of worsening chest pain and breathlessness during exercise. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Auscultation of the chest shows a murmur in the 2nd right intercostal space. A phonocardiogram of the murmur is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

M protein cross-reactivity is the underlying cause of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). In RHD, antibodies to streptococcal M protein cross-react with valvular proteins, resulting in valve inflammation, fibrosis, and stenosis. While RHD is the most common cause of AS in developing countries, it is relatively uncommon in the United States.

B) INCORRECT:

Metastatic calcification of the valves occurs in previously healthy tissue due to chronic hypercalcemia or hyperphosphatemia (as opposed to dystrophic calcification). Aortic stenosis caused by metastatic calcification would manifest with dyspnea and chest pain. However, this patient has no underlying condition that would predispose to metastatic calcification, which includes primary hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, sarcoidosis, and chronic kidney disease.

C) CORRECT:

Congenital aortic valve leaflet fusion is the most likely cause of aortic stenosis (AS) in this patient. AS is the most common valvular heart disease in industrialized countries, with incidence increasing with age. In patients < 70 years presenting with AS, a congenital bicuspid aortic valve abnormality is most likely responsible. This pathology predisposes the valve to dystrophic calcification and degeneration that occurs earlier than calcific aortic stenosis associated with old age.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Cystic medial necrosis is the pathology underlying aneurysmal dilation of the thoracic aorta and the aortic root, which is associated with hypertension, bicuspid aortic valve, and connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome. If the aortic root is sufficiently dilated, these patients can present with aortic regurgitation and symptoms such as dyspnea and chest pain. However, cystic medial necrosis is not associated with aortic stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Sterile platelet thrombi can form on cardiac valves in patients with nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE), which is usually associated with rheumatologic disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus) or malignancies. While patients with NBTE can present with dyspnea and chest pain, there is no indication of an underlying pathology in this patient. Furthermore, NBTE is associated with aortic or mitral regurgitation, not aortic stenosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Viridans group streptococci are associated with subacute bacterial endocarditis, which can cause regurgitant valvular lesions, e.g., mitral or aortic regurgitation, manifesting with dyspnea. However, infectious endocarditis does not typically cause aortic stenosis. Furthermore, the patient here has no systemic symptoms that could be attributed to subacute bacterial endocarditis, e.g., fever, malaise, and/or tachycardia.
questions.hint: The phonocardiogram shows a crescendo-decrescendo murmur during systole. Such a murmur at the aortic area (2nd intercostal space) is characteristic of aortic stenosis, which can manifest with angina, dyspnea, and/or lightheadedness.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for a 2-month history of progressive shortness of breath during exercise and episodic chest pain. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac auscultation shows a murmur. Left-heart catheterization is performed. A graph representing the results of the catheterization is shown. The intensity of this patient's cardiac murmur is most likely to be greatest at which of the following labeled points along the timeline?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Point A marks a point in the timeline during the isovolumetric contraction phase (early systole) shortly before the aortic valve opens. However, the characteristic crescendo-decrescendo murmur in aortic stenosis will be loudest during the systolic ejection phase, when there is blood flow through the aortic valve.

B) CORRECT:

This patient most likely presents with aortic stenosis (AS), which is associated with an increased pressure gradient across the aortic valve during ventricular ejection. The ventricular ejection phase starts when the left ventricular pressure exceeds the aortic pressure and forces the aortic valve to open. In aortic stenosis, the characteristic harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur is caused by the turbulent blood flow through the narrowed aortic opening. The intensity of this murmur will be loudest during the ventricular ejection phase at the peak of the aorto-ventricular pressure gradient, which is the point in the timeline marked with B.

C) INCORRECT:

Point C marks the point in the timeline during which aortic valve closure occurs, producing the second heart sound (closure of the pulmonic valve also contributes to this sound). In patients with aortic stenosis (AS), the second heart sound is typically soft because of delayed closure and reduced mobility of the aortic valve. However, the characteristic crescendo-decrescendo murmur in AS will be loudest during the systolic ejection phase, when there is blood flow through the aortic valve.

D) INCORRECT:

Point D marks a point in the timeline during the ventricular filling phase, when blood flows through the mitral valve into the left ventricle. However, the characteristic crescendo-decrescendo murmur in AS will be loudest during the systolic ejection phase, when there is blood flow through the aortic valve.

E) INCORRECT:

Point E marks the point in the timeline during which the contraction of the left atrium (i.e., left atrial systole) occurs and blood is ejected from the left atrium through the mitral valve into the left ventricle. Longstanding aortic stenosis (AS) is associated with left ventricular hypertrophy, which decreases ventricle compliance. As a result, patients with AS may present with a fourth heart sound, which is caused by late diastolic contraction of the left atrium against a noncompliant left ventricle. However, the characteristic crescendo-decrescendo murmur in AS will be loudest during systole, when there is blood flow through the aortic valve.
questions.hint: The graph shows a peak ventricular pressure that is significantly higher than the peak aortic pressure. This finding is classically seen in aortic stenosis (AS) and can be explained by an elevated ventricular pressure required to pump blood through the stenotic aortic valve.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is found to have a murmur during routine evaluation. He has no symptoms and denies any physical limitations, but he has not exercised regularly since high school.
He has a nondisplaced point of maximal impulse, a normal first heart sound, and a physiologically split second heart sound. A short early systolic click is heard at the apex, followed by a soft ejection murmur that is more evident at the right upper sternal border and does not vary with respiration or the Valsalva maneuver. Examination of his carotid and peripheral pulses is unremarkable. His blood pressure is normal and equal in all four extremities.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can produce a harsh ejection murmur, also similar to that of aortic stenosis, but the murmur typically increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver. An ejection click is usually absent.

B) INCORRECT:

The lack of variation in intensity with respiration argues against pulmonary-valve stenosis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s physical examination findings are most consistent with a bicuspid aortic valve. An ejection click followed by an ejection murmur is consistent with a bicuspid aortic valve and minimal or only mild aortic stenosis. The presence of normal peripheral pulses (absence of decreased or delayed pulses) and a physiologically split second heart sound both argue against severe aortic-valve stenosis.

Bicuspid aortic valve is present in 1% to 2% of adults and is more common in men. Patients with a bicuspid aortic valve are at increased risk for aortic stenosis, aortic regurgitation, or both, typically in the fourth to sixth decades of life. A bicuspid aortic valve is also associated with aortopathy, ascending aortic aneurysm, and increased risk for aortic dissection.

Key learning point: A short early systolic sound heard at the apex, followed by a soft ejection murmur that is more evident at the right upper sternal border and does not vary with respiration, is likely to be secondary to a bicuspid aortic valve.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of normal peripheral pulses (absence of decreased or delayed pulses) and a physiologically split second heart sound both argue against severe aortic-valve stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic-valve thickening or sclerosis is typically seen in older patients and is not usually associated with an ejection click. The more common finding is a midsystolic ejection murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border, mimicking true aortic stenosis.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoporosis presents for an annual visit. She is active and walks 15 to 20 minutes per day. She is concerned because she cannot walk as quickly or as far as she could a year ago. She states that she does not experience angina, palpitations, orthopnea, or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.
Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 154/86 mm Hg, a regular heart rate at 72 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while breathing ambient air. Jugular venous pulsations are appreciated at 7 cm above the sternal angle at 45 degrees. The carotid pulses are decreased and delayed.
The patient has a normal first heart sound and a diminished aortic component of the second heart sound, with a 3/6 late-peaking crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur. The murmur is heard best at the right-upper-sternal border, with radiation to the neck. No third heart sound is audible, but a left ventricular fourth heart sound is appreciated. The point of maximum impulse is laterally displaced.
The patient’s lungs are clear to auscultation and percussion. She has mild bilateral lower-extremity edema.
Which one of the following evaluations is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Electrocardiographically gated CT of the heart

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carotid ultrasonography is not indicated in a patient who has no cerebrovascular symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Stress testing is generally contraindicated in patients with severe, symptomatic aortic stenosis. Determining the severity of the aortic stenosis via echocardiography would be indicated before performing stress testing.

C) CORRECT:

Physical examination is critical in detecting aortic stenosis but is relatively poor at predicting its severity. Findings that suggest severe valvular obstruction include decreased and/or delayed carotid pulses, a late-peaking systolic murmur, and a soft or absent aortic component of the second heart sound. Lower-extremity edema and elevated jugular venous pressure suggest congestive heart failure.

Reduced exercise capacity and a significant systolic murmur suggestive of severe, calcific aortic stenosis warrant noninvasive quantification with transthoracic echocardiography.

Key learning point: A common initial symptom in adults with severe aortic stenosis is a decrease in exercise capacity. Other symptoms may include angina-like chest pain, congestive heart failure, and syncope.

D) INCORRECT:

CT of the heart does not assess the severity of valvular stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization to assess hemodynamics or to perform coronary angiography may be indicated preoperatively in some patients with aortic stenosis, but it is not appropriate as the initial test.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with shortness of breath, chest pressure, and lower-extremity swelling. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
His vital signs on admission include a blood pressure of 148/94 mm Hg, a heart rate of 90 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 91% while he is breathing ambient air.
His jugular venous pressure is elevated to 10 cm above the manubriosternal angle. Inspiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. S1 is normal; S2 is only heard faintly at the right upper sternal border. He has a crescendo-decrescendo midsystolic grade 3/6 murmur that is loudest at the right upper sternal border, with radiation to the neck and also to the apex. The carotid pulse is low-volume and slow-rising.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonic stenosis is usually a congenital abnormality; when it is acquired in adulthood, it is often associated with carcinoid syndrome. Pulmonic stenosis, like AS, causes a crescendo-decrescendo midsystolic murmur, but it is best heard at the upper left sternal border. In addition, severe pulmonic stenosis would cause right heart (not left heart) failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic sclerosis is the term used for calcification and thickening of aortic valve leaflets, without a gradient across the valve. Because the valve is not yet stenotic (by definition) in aortic sclerosis, patients are asymptomatic. Patients with aortic sclerosis often have a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur similar to that of aortic stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Because the murmur of aortic stenosis often radiates to the apex (as well as to the neck), clinicians may wonder whether an additional murmur of mitral regurgitation is present. However, murmurs of mitral regurgitation in patients with heart failure are usually pansystolic with radiation to the axilla.

D) INCORRECT:

Severe tricuspid regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur heard best along the mid- to lower sternal borders. Many patients with tricuspid regurgitation have a visible rise and fall of the jugular venous wave with each heartbeat. This so-called “V wave” corresponds to the regurgitant jet of blood during systole and the return of blood to the right heart during diastole.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s physical examination findings suggest left heart failure secondary to severe aortic stenosis (AS). Severe AS is associated with a low-volume, slow-rising carotid pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus), a late-peaking crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur, and a diminished or absent aortic component of the second heart sound correlate with severe AS (valve area <1.0 cm2). The diminished intensity of S2 occurs because the calcified aortic leaflets in AS become relatively immobile.

Key learning point: A low-volume, slow-rising carotid pulse, a diminished aortic component of the second heart sound, and a late-peaking systolic ejection murmur are clinical signs of severe aortic stenosis.

questions.text:
A generally healthy 81-year-old woman reports a 3-month history of progressive dyspnea during household activities.
She has a harsh, grade 3/6, late-peaking, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur; a delayed carotid upstroke; and trace lower-extremity edema. Her laboratory results are within normal limits.
An echocardiogram reveals severe aortic stenosis, with a mean transvalvular pressure gradient of 45 mm Hg, and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Refer for percutaneous aortic balloon valvuloplasty
Prescribe an angiotensin-receptor blocker and observe
Refer for transcatheter aortic valve replacement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous aortic balloon valvuloplasty is associated with a high incidence of complications and restenosis, which leads to poor intermediate- and long-term outcomes.

B) INCORRECT:

Stress testing is contraindicated in a symptomatic patient with severe aortic stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

An implantable cardioverter-defibrillator does not address the aortic stenosis, so it is unlikely to alter the natural history.

D) INCORRECT:

The definitive treatment for severe, symptomatic aortic stenosis is replacement of the aortic valve, even if the left ventricular ejection fraction is depressed; medications alone (e.g., an angiotensin-receptor blocker) are inadequate. Notably, the left ventricular ejection fraction improves and often normalizes following surgery.

E) CORRECT:

Aortic stenosis has a relatively benign clinical course until symptoms develop, at which point the prognosis changes dramatically. The development of angina, syncope, or heart failure in the setting of aortic stenosis is associated with a median survival of 5, 3, and 2 years, respectively. Heart failure symptoms in patients with aortic stenosis often consist of exertional dyspnea rather than orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.

The definitive treatment for severe, symptomatic aortic stenosis is replacement of the aortic valve, even if the left ventricular ejection fraction is depressed; medications alone (e.g., an angiotensin-receptor blocker) are inadequate. Notably, the left ventricular ejection fraction improves and often normalizes following surgery.

In this case, the patient is older and, if she has favorable anatomy, would be a candidate for transcatheter aortic valve replacement rather than the traditional surgical approach. If her anatomy is not favorable, a surgical approach should be pursued. Many centers have a multidisciplinary heart team that will discuss the benefits and risks of both options before making a recommendation.

Key learning point: In a patient with severe aortic stenosis and symptoms of heart failure, the best treatment approach is referral for aortic valve replacement.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman is noted to have a systolic ejection murmur. She has no chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. She reports that she leads a sedentary life, rarely leaving her house except to drive to do errands such as grocery shopping.
Her blood pressure is 135/86 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 67 beats per minute. She has a 3/6 late-peaking crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur, heard best at the right upper sternal border, with a delayed carotid upstroke. No crackles are detected on pulmonary auscultation, and there is no lower-extremity edema.
A recent echocardiogram reveals a calcified aortic valve with a peak velocity of 3.8 m/sec, a mean transvalvular pressure gradient of 42 mm Hg, and an aortic valve area of 0.9 cm2 . Left ventricular systolic function is 65%.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with an angiotensin-receptor blocker

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s physical examination and echocardiographic findings point to severe aortic stenosis at stage C1. Severe aortic stenosis is typically associated with a mean transvalvular pressure gradient >40 mm Hg or a peak aortic velocity ≥4.0 m/sec.

Aortic valve replacement is indicated for patients with severe aortic stenosis who are undergoing other cardiac surgery, who have a left ventricular ejection fraction <50%, or who have symptoms from severe outflow obstruction, such as chest pain, dyspnea, presyncope, or syncope. In this case, the patient reports no symptoms, but her functional capacity is unclear; thus, it is reasonable to perform exercise stress testing to confirm the absence of symptoms. Asymptomatic aortic stenosis, even if severe by echocardiographic criteria, is currently managed medically, although the potential benefits of aortic valve replacement in this setting are being explored in multiple ongoing trials.

Key learning point: When a patient with severe aortic stenosis does not report symptoms, confirming the absence of symptoms with exercise testing would be reasonable, because the presence of symptoms would be an indication for aortic valve replacement.

B) INCORRECT:

No drug therapies have been shown to change the natural history of aortic stenosis. If a patient also has hypertension, antihypertensive drug therapy should be considered, but low doses should be prescribed initially, and some experts recommend that diuretics be avoided.

C) INCORRECT:

Left heart catheterization can be helpful in identifying disease severity when echocardiographic and physical examination findings are inconsistent. There is no such ambiguity in this patient’s presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

No drug therapies have been shown to change the natural history of aortic stenosis. If a patient also has hypertension, antihypertensive drug therapy should be considered, but low doses should be prescribed initially, and some experts recommend that diuretics be avoided.

E) INCORRECT:

Aortic valve replacement is indicated for patients with severe aortic stenosis who are undergoing other cardiac surgery, who have a left ventricular ejection fraction <50%, or who have symptoms from severe outflow obstruction, such as chest pain, dyspnea, presyncope, or syncope.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man with hypertension reports slight dyspnea and chest tightness when walking uphill or climbing stairs during the past year. His blood pressure has been well controlled on hydrochlorothiazide and enalapril.
On physical examination, a harsh grade 3/6 crescendo-decrescendo murmur, typical of aortic stenosis, is heard maximally at the upper right sternal border. His lungs are clear to auscultation, and he has no peripheral edema.
Which one of the following additional physical findings is most consistent with a diagnosis of severe aortic stenosis?

choices.text: Radiation of the murmur to the neck
A soft or absent aortic component of the second heart sound
Presence of a fourth heart sound
A loud aortic component of the second heart sound

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A bounding carotid pulse is common in patients with severe aortic regurgitation. In patients with aortic stenosis, the pulse wave is typically blunted and delayed (“pulsus parvus et tardus”).

B) INCORRECT:

Radiation of the murmur of aortic stenosis to the neck does not correlate with severity.

C) CORRECT:

As aortic stenosis progresses, the valve leaflets become stiffer and less mobile, and the aortic component of the second heart sound (S2) gradually becomes softer. In some cases, the aortic component becomes inaudible. When S2 is clearly softer (or inaudible) over the aortic area than over the pulmonic area, the gradient across the aortic valve is likely to be substantial, and the aortic stenosis severe.

Key learning point: The physical finding most indicative of severe, rather than mild, aortic stenosis is a soft or absent aortic component of the second heart sound.

D) INCORRECT:

A fourth heart sound suggests left ventricular hypertrophy. Because left ventricular hypertrophy is common in older patients with hypertension (as well as with aortic stenosis), presence of a fourth heart sound would not reliably indicate that the aortic stenosis is severe.

E) INCORRECT:

As aortic stenosis progresses, the valve leaflets become stiffer and less mobile, and the aortic component of the second heart sound (S2) gradually becomes softer. In some cases, the aortic component becomes inaudible. When S2 is clearly softer (or inaudible) over the aortic area than over the pulmonic area, the gradient across the aortic valve is likely to be substantial, and the aortic stenosis severe.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man reports 3 weeks of intermittent palpitations and associated mild dyspnea. He has a history of coronary artery disease, a bicuspid aortic valve and underwent mechanical bileaflet aortic valve replacement 3 years ago. He reports no chest pain, orthopnea, or lower-extremity edema. His current medications are warfarin 5 mg daily and aspirin 81 mg daily.
He has a normal blood pressure and a normal heart rate. Cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm and a grade 1/6 early systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border, with no extra heart sounds.
Laboratory evaluation is notable for an international normalized ratio (INR) of 2.3. Electrocardiography reveals atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 89 beats per minute.
Which one of the following adjustments, if any, should be made to this patient’s anticoagulation regimen?

choices.text: Stop warfarin, and start rivaroxaban 15 mg twice daily
Adjust the warfarin dose to achieve an INR within the target of 2.5 to 3.5
Increase the aspirin dose to 325 mg daily
Stop warfarin, and start dabigatran 150 mg twice daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation with warfarin is indicated in patients with a mechanical aortic valve; the target international normalized ratio (INR) in these patients is usually 2.0 to 3.0. However, if the patient has any additional risk factors for thromboembolism — such as atrial fibrillation (which this patient has), left ventricular dysfunction, previous thromboembolism, or hypercoagulable conditions — a higher INR target of 2.5 to 3.5 is indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Direct oral anticoagulants, such as rivaroxaban and dabigatran, have not been adequately studied in patients with mechanical prosthetic valves and are therefore not indicated for thromboembolic protection in this patient population.

C) CORRECT:

Anticoagulation with warfarin is indicated in patients with a mechanical aortic valve; the target international normalized ratio (INR) in these patients is usually 2.0 to 3.0. However, if the patient has any additional risk factors for thromboembolism — such as atrial fibrillation (which this patient has), left ventricular dysfunction, previous thromboembolism, or hypercoagulable conditions — a higher INR target of 2.5 to 3.5 is indicated. The recommended daily dose of aspirin (81 mg) remains unchanged with the history of coronary artery disease.

Key learning point: In a patient with a mechanical aortic valve and atrial fibrillation who is receiving warfarin, the appropriate INR target is 2.5 to 3.5.

D) INCORRECT:

The recommended daily dose of aspirin (81 mg) remains unchanged with the history of coronary artery disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Direct oral anticoagulants, such as rivaroxaban and dabigatran, have not been adequately studied in patients with mechanical prosthetic valves and are therefore not indicated for thromboembolic protection in this patient population.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old male infant is being seen in the newborn nursery. He was born at a gestational age of 40 weeks and 5 days by spontaneous vaginal delivery that was complicated by meconium-stained amniotic fluid. He has been breastfeeding and had normal urine output for the first 24 hours of life. Shortly after birth, a 3/6 murmur was heard, and an echocardiogram was ordered. On day 2 of life, he was noted to have less interest in feeding and to tire with feeding. He has been difficult to arouse at times, and urine output has been minimal.
On examination, he has a heart rate of 187 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 75 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 46/22 mm Hg in both the upper and lower extremities. He is not cyanotic but does appear mottled. Cardiac examination reveals a 1/6 systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur at the right upper sternal border. Breath sounds are equal bilaterally. The abdomen is soft with a liver edge palpable 3 cm below the costal margin. Pulses in all extremities are 1+ and thready.
Prostaglandin E2 infusion is started, and the patient is transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit. An echocardiogram is obtained (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Total anomalous pulmonary venous return is a rare form of cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary veins drain to a location other than the left atrium. The pulmonary veins can drain to various places, including the systemic venous system above or below the diaphragm. If the pulmonary venous drainage is obstructed anywhere along its pathway, the infant can present with significant pulmonary edema and cardiogenic shock immediately after birth. The infant would not be expected to have a murmur of aortic stenosis and would be cyanotic.

B) INCORRECT:

Tetralogy of Fallot is a form of congenital heart disease named for a group of four classic cardiac findings: ventricular septal defect, right ventricular outflow-tract obstruction, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an aorta that overrides the ventricular septal defect. The murmur is typically that of pulmonary stenosis, and affected patients are unlikely to present (as this neonate does) with cardiogenic shock and ductal-dependent pulmonary blood flow. Infants with tetralogy of Fallot may also present with cyanosis, although this finding varies and depends on the degree of pulmonary stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A ventricular septal defect allows for shunting between the left and right ventricles. Depending on the size of the lesion and the relative pressure difference across the ventricular septum, blood can shunt in either direction with a wide range of velocities. Typically, blood shunts from left to right and creates a classic holosystolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border. A clinically significant ventricular septal defect usually manifests with pulmonary overcirculation, tachypnea, and failure to thrive; it would be unlikely to cause cardiogenic shock, especially at such a young age.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis can lead to shock in a newborn, but the murmur would be loudest at the left upper sternal border and would be heard radiating to the back. If the pulmonary stenosis were critical, with the ductus arteriosus required for adequate pulmonary blood flow, hypoxia would also be expected.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has evidence of cardiogenic shock, secondary to critical aortic stenosis. The murmur of aortic stenosis is a systolic murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border and is crescendo-decrescendo in quality. This infant’s murmur was likely to have been louder at birth but declined in amplitude to the 1/6 murmur noted on examination as the cardiac output dropped. The echocardiogram shows significant flow acceleration and turbulence across the aortic valve, which also suggests significant aortic stenosis.

Infants with critical aortic stenosis typically appear to be well after birth but are dependent on their patent ductus arteriosus to support systemic blood flow. As the ductus arteriosus closes during the first several days of life, cardiac output drops and signs of cardiogenic shock develop, often rapidly. Classic signs include pallor, cool skin, poor pulses, tachycardia, a diminished murmur, and hepatosplenomegaly. In less severe disease, infants typically present with a murmur but may also exhibit failure to thrive because of feeding difficulty related to tachypnea.

Key learning point: In a newborn with cardiogenic shock and a systolic ejection murmur heard loudest at the right upper sternal border, the most likely diagnosis is critical aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the clinic because of a 3-month history of chest pain, dyspnea on mild exertion, and episodic loss of consciousness. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and obstructive sleep apnea, for which he uses nocturnal PAP. The patient is widowed, lives alone, and has two adult children. Medications are amlodipine and ramipril. He does not drink alcoholic beverages or smoke cigarettes. He is not in acute distress. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (181 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Cardiac examination reveals an S4 heart sound most prominent at the apex and a grade 4 late systolic ejection murmur best heard in the second right intercostal space. The murmur radiates bilaterally to the carotids and decreases in intensity with handgrip. Which of the following factors in this patient most strongly predicts a poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Angina pectoris due to myocardial ischemia and syncope caused by poor cerebral perfusion are symptoms of severe AS and are associated with a poor prognosis. Approximately half of patients with AS die within 5 years after the onset of angina, and half die within 3 years after the onset of syncope. However, another factor in this patient more strongly predicts a poor prognosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Murmur radiation to the carotids is a typical clinical feature of AS. However, in severe AS, the radiated murmur may become barely audible due to left ventricular failure and decreased cardiac output. Therefore, this clinical sign is not the most significant prognostic factor for AS.

C) CORRECT:

Dyspnea is an early sign of heart failure, which occurs in severe AS as a result of left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. While patients with AS can be asymptomatic for years, the onset of symptoms usually indicates a progression to severe AS. Mortality rates increase from less than 1% per year in asymptomatic patients to over 50% within the first two years after the onset of symptoms if left untreated. Dyspnea is the strongest predictor of a poor prognosis, followed by syncope and angina pectoris. Approximately half of AS patients with dyspnea die within 2 years of symptom onset. Aortic valve replacement can slow the rapid decline in life expectancy after the onset of symptoms.

Dihydropyridines (e.g., amlodipine) are contraindicated in patients with severe stenotic heart valve defects. This patient should be switched to another antihypertensive.

D) INCORRECT:

An S4 heart sound indicates ventricular hypertrophy and results from late diastolic atrial contraction against high ventricular pressure. In young patients, S4 heart sound signifies severe AS. In older individuals, an S4 heart sound may occur in the absence of overt heart disease and is therefore not the strongest predictor of poor prognosis in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

The timing and duration of the systolic murmur correlate with the severity of AS. Mild to moderate AS typically manifests with an early peaking murmur, while severe AS is characterized by a longer late systolic murmur. While most murmurs with an intensity of grade 3 or higher are pathological, their intensity does not always correlate with the clinical severity of the underlying lesion. The murmur in severe AS decreases in intensity and may even disappear once the patient develops left heart failure.
questions.hint: A grade 4 late systolic ejection murmur best heard at the second right intercostal space and radiating bilaterally to the carotids indicates aortic valve stenosis (AS).

questions.text: An 81-year-old man comes to the office because of increased exertional dyspnea and dizziness over the past 8 weeks. He has hypertension for which he takes lisinopril. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space that radiates to the carotids. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary stenosis is mostly a congenital valve defect that can also manifest with exertional dyspnea. In adults, common causes include carcinoid syndrome and chronic rheumatic fever. But auscultation yields an ejection systolic murmur best heard in the left 2nd ICS.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, patients with MR would have normal peripheral pulses and a holosystolic high-pitched murmur heard best at the left midclavicular line of the 5th ICS that radiates to the left axilla.
Image Description:

Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

C) CORRECT:

This patient's auscultation findings are consistent with aortic stenosis (AS), which causes left ventricular outflow obstruction. The result is dizziness and exacerbation of dyspnea upon exertion, and weak, delayed peripheral pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus). Incomplete left ventricular emptying may also cause pulmonary venous congestion, which further exacerbates dyspnea.
Image Description:

A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

D) INCORRECT:

Mitral stenosis (MS) leads to pulmonary venous congestion, which, in turn, causes dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, auscultation in MS yields a mid-diastolic murmur heard best at the midclavicular 5th left ICS (the apex), and is often preceded by an opening snap.
Image Description:

Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with severe aortic regurgitation can present with dizziness and exertional dyspnea, like this patient. However, examination in AR would show a high pulse pressure, a water hammer pulse, and a high-pitched early diastolic murmur heard best at the 2nd right ICS that does not radiate to the carotid arteries.
Image Description:

Early-diastolic decrescendo murmur (directly after the second heart sound), consistent with aortic regurgitation and/or pulmonary regurgitation.
questions.hint: Auscultation shows a harsh crescendo-decrescendo, systolic ejection murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space (ICS) that radiates to the carotids. These features are suggestive of the most common valvular heart disease in industrialized countries.

questions.text: A 79-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with shortness of breath, chest pressure, and lower-extremity swelling. Vital signs on admission include a pulse of 90/min, blood pressure of 148/94 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 91% while he is breathing ambient air. His jugular venous pressure is elevated to 10 cm above the manubriosternal angle. Inspiratory crackles are heard at both lung bases. S1 is normal; S2 is only heard faintly at the right upper sternal border. He has a crescendo-decrescendo midsystolic grade 3/6 murmur that is loudest at the right upper sternal border, with radiation to the neck and also to the apex. The carotid pulse is low-volume and slow-rising. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonic stenosis is usually a congenital abnormality; when it is acquired in adulthood, it is often associated with carcinoid syndrome. Pulmonic stenosis, like AS, causes a crescendo-decrescendo midsystolic murmur, but it is best heard at the upper left sternal border. In addition, severe pulmonic stenosis would cause right heart (not left heart) failure.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic sclerosis is the term used for calcification and thickening of aortic valve leaflets, without a gradient across the valve. Because the valve is not yet stenotic (by definition) in aortic sclerosis, patients are asymptomatic. Patients with aortic sclerosis often have a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur similar to that of aortic stenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Because the murmur of aortic stenosis often radiates to the apex (as well as to the neck), clinicians may wonder whether an additional murmur of mitral regurgitation is present. However, murmurs of mitral regurgitation in patients with heart failure are usually pansystolic with radiation to the axilla.

D) INCORRECT:

Severe tricuspid regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur heard best along the mid- to lower sternal borders. Many patients with tricuspid regurgitation have a visible rise and fall of the jugular venous wave with each heartbeat. This so-called “V wave” corresponds to the regurgitant jet of blood during systole and the return of blood to the right heart during diastole.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s physical examination findings suggest left heart failure secondary to severe aortic stenosis (AS). Severe AS is associated with a low-volume, slow-rising carotid pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus), a late-peaking crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur, and a diminished or absent aortic component of the second heart sound correlate with severe AS (valve area <1.0 cm2). The diminished intensity of S2 occurs because the calcified aortic leaflets in AS become relatively immobile.

Key learning point: A low-volume, slow-rising carotid pulse, a diminished aortic component of the second heart sound, and a late-peaking systolic ejection murmur are clinical signs of severe aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband 20 minutes after losing consciousness. She was walking briskly with her husband when she collapsed suddenly. Her husband says that she regained consciousness after 1 minute. She has had episodes of mild chest pain for the past 2 months, especially when working in the garden. Physical examination shows a grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur. The intensity of the murmur decreases with the handgrip maneuver and does not change with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Cystic medial degeneration of the aortic root
Sterile platelet thrombi on the mitral valve
Dystrophic calcification on the aortic valve
Granulomatous nodules on the mitral valve
Congenital leaflet fusion of the aortic valve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystic medial degeneration of the aortic root, which occurs in Marfan syndrome, can lead to aortic regurgitation. Unlike this patient's murmur, the murmur of aortic regurgitation is holodiastolic and accentuated by maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., handgrip). Moreover, this patient does not have any features that suggest a diagnosis of Marfan syndrome (e.g., long extremities, hypermobile joints, arachnodactyly, blurred vision due to lens dislocation).

B) INCORRECT:

Sterile platelet thrombi on the mitral valve are characteristic of nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE), which can occur in individuals with rheumatologic disorders (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus) or malignancies. NBTE can result in mitral regurgitation. Unlike this patient's murmur, the murmur of mitral regurgitation is holosystolic. Moreover, this patient lacks manifestations that suggest an underlying rheumatologic disorder (e.g., fever, joint pain, malaise) and does not have a known malignancy.

C) CORRECT:

The most common cause of aortic valve stenosis (AS) is dystrophic calcification of the aortic valve. AS is the most common valvular abnormality in adults > 65 years of age. Typical symptoms include syncope (especially during physical exercise), angina pectoris, and dyspnea (typically exertional). Cardiac auscultation in a patient with AS typically reveals a mid-to-late-peaking systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is heard best at the aortic area (right upper sternal border). Maneuvers that increase afterload (e.g., sustained handgrip) decrease the intensity of the murmur.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatous nodules on the mitral valve are associated with rheumatic heart disease (RHD) and can result in mitral regurgitation. RHD typically manifests during adolescence or early adulthood and is an unlikely underlying cause of a murmur in this 79-year-old patient. Moreover, the handgrip maneuver increases the intensity of the murmur of mitral regurgitation.

E) INCORRECT:

A bicuspid aortic valve due to congenital fusion of the aortic valve leaflets can lead to aortic stenosis and manifest with syncope, chest pain, and a late-peaking systolic murmur that decreases in intensity with the handgrip maneuver. However, aortic stenosis due to a bicuspid valve typically becomes symptomatic in the fourth or fifth decade of life. This 79-year-old patient is more likely to have aortic stenosis of a different etiology.
questions.hint: Physical examination of this patient is likely to show pulsus parvus et tardus.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the office for an annual visit. She is concerned because she cannot walk as quickly or as far as she could a year ago. Her pulse is 72/min, respirations are 12/minute, and blood pressure is 154/86 mm Hg. Jugular venous pulsations are appreciated at 7 cm above the sternal angle at 45 degrees. The carotid pulses are decreased and delayed. The patient has a diminished aortic component of the second heart sound, with a 3/6 late-peaking crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best at the right-upper-sternal border, with radiation to the neck. A left ventricular fourth heart sound is appreciated. She has mild bilateral lower-extremity edema. Which one of the following evaluations is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Electrocardiographically gated CT of the heart

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carotid ultrasonography is not indicated in a patient who has no cerebrovascular symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Stress testing is generally contraindicated in patients with severe, symptomatic aortic stenosis. Determining the severity of the aortic stenosis via echocardiography would be indicated before performing stress testing.

C) CORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is warranted for noninvasive quantification in patients with reduced exercise capacity and a significant systolic murmur suggestive of severe, calcific aortic stenosis. Physical examination is critical in detecting aortic stenosis but is relatively poor at predicting its severity.

Key learning point: A common initial symptom in adults with severe aortic stenosis is a decrease in exercise capacity. Other symptoms may include angina-like chest pain, congestive heart failure, and syncope.

D) INCORRECT:

CT of the heart does not assess the severity of valvular stenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization to assess hemodynamics or to perform coronary angiography may be indicated preoperatively in some patients with aortic stenosis, but it is not appropriate as the initial test.
